personalized_feedback:
Vihaan — I’m really pleased with how you’ve moved from scattered ideas to a clear, repeatable process. You’ve become deliberate about framing each finance question (you define the decision, the key drivers, and the data needed before building anything), you articulate assumptions explicitly, and you validate outputs against intuitive benchmarks. Those concrete habits — hypothesis-first thinking, clearly-stated assumptions, and systematic validation — are exactly the DRIVER transformation I want to see: your “monkey mind” is turning into a disciplined analyst.

For next steps, treat the one remaining technical gap and the continuing finance/tech integration as practical experiments tied to real business problems. First, strengthen model robustness: for any valuation or cash-flow model you produce, add a short “robustness checklist” — boundary cases, sensitivity sweeps, and one reconciliation to financial statements (e.g., tie your free cash flow back to reported net income and working capital changes). That will close remaining accuracy issues and make your outputs usable by a CFO. Second, deepen integration: pick one routine deliverable (monthly cash forecast, scenario P&L) and automate its refresh path — define the data source, the transformation rules, and a simple validation step so a non-technical manager can trust the results. These are the exact capabilities that make you valuable in finance teams.

Keep pushing this way. Systematic thinking is a career multiplier: it speeds decisions, reduces rework, and makes your recommendations defensible. Treat each project as another DRIVER iteration — clarify the decision, iterate the model, validate with stakeholders, and deliver a reproducible product. I’m excited to see where you take this next; you’re building a professional muscle that will pay dividends in any finance role.
